div.div: Selenium
Chapter . What is IDE

Your IDE needs a plugin called SpecFlow in order to functionate properly and red your tests.

Chapter . Locators

Locators can be found with many possible ways. One of them is by Id which is the most reliable one.

div.p: An integrated development environment (IDE) is a software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development. An IDE normally consists of at least a source code editor, build automation tools and a debugger. Some IDEs, such as NetBeans and Eclipse, contain the necessary compiler, interpreter, or both; others, such as SharpDevelop and Lazarus, do not.

The boundary between an IDE and other parts of the broader software development environment is not well-defined; sometimes a version control system or various tools to simplify the construction of a graphical user interface (GUI) are integrated. Many modern IDEs also have a class browser, an object browser, and a class hierarchy diagram for use in object-oriented software development.
What to use IDE for : Syntax Highlighting

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: Selenium is a free (open-source) automated testing framework used to validate web applications across different browsers and platforms. You can use multiple programming languages like Java, C#, Python etc to create Selenium Test Scripts. Testing done using the Selenium testing tool is usually referred to as Selenium Testing.
Selenium Software is not just a single tool but a suite of software, each piece catering to different Selenium QA testing needs of an organization.Here is the list of tools

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

h1.span: Pros and cons of automation testing

div.p: Just like everything - automation testing has its pros and cons. Here we will look at the pros and cons of the automation process.

tr.td: Reduce the time required to regression
Unstable outcomes and false test alarms due to their poor design and implementation
Mistakes in automated tests lead to errors and omissions
Get an infinite number of test runs when using continuous software development mechanisms
Reduce the number of manual tests
Due to strict algorithms, automated tests can find only part of mistakes
Detect errors overlooked during manual testing
Much time is needed to support automation

div.p: In addition there are couple of things to take care when you automate such as

ol.li: Not all test cases need to be automated
Time needed for automation testing is comparable to the time spent on software development
Before writing automated tests you need to work on test system architecture. Otherwise apart from manual testing you will need to support automated tests
When implementing automation, it is impossible to foresee all the risks and challenges you might face in the future

h2.span: How to add SpecFlow into your project

div.p: Your IDE needs a plugin called SpecFlow in order to functionate properly and red your tests.

section.p: Get familiar with what IDE is
Here you will learn how to add SpecFlow into your project :

li.span: Open Visual Studio.
Go to Extensions.
Then go to Manage Extensions.
Choose online.
In the search box type SpecFlow.
Hit the download button to begin the installation procces

section.p: Your IDE will be able to read your tests
The Blue color of the Given, When, Then means the IDE reads the tests.

div.p: To run your test you need steps to be followed. In the future files you will write down your steps. Every web page in the given web site needs a separate feature file.

section.p: You will learn how to create feature files :

li.span: Create a separate folder for the feature files in the project
Click with the right button of the mouse on the folder
Choose new item
Navigate to SpecFlow
Choose the top option
Name the file in the name field
Click on Add

section.p: You will be able to write down your tests.
For Example:

div.section: You want to create a couple of tests for a Login.

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: In order to perform an automation test we need locators for the Selenium to perform actions on.

section.p: In this topic we gonna found out how to create locators :

li.span: Create a class named after the web page you are on ( every page of the web site must have separte class).
Create a variable as a private of type IWebElement.
Name the variable.

section.p: You will learn how to find locators.
For Example:

div.section: You want to click on a login button. To do that you have to find the locator and perform action on it.

h2.span: How to find locators by Id

div.p: Locators can be found with many possible ways. One of them is by Id which is the most reliable one.

section.p: Read how to create locator variables.
You will find out how to find locators by id :

li.span: Create a locator
Go to the dom in the web site and search for the id of the given web element
Use lambda => after the locator's name or =
Use the command driver.FindBy(By.id()) after the lambda
Put the id into the By.id brackets

section.p: You will be able to perform action on the locator

h2.span: How to find locators by Class Name

div.p: Locators can be found with many possible ways. One of them is by class name which is the most reliable one after id.

section.p: Read how to create local variables

div.section: You will find out how to find locators by class name :

li.span: Create a locator
Go to the dom in the web site and search for the class name of the given web element
Use lambda => after the locator's name or =
Use the command driver.FindBy(By.className()) after the lambda
Put the class into the by.className brackets

section.p: You will be able to perform action on the locator

div.domains: (map mapgroup-d) (topic abbrev-d) (topic delay-d) a(props deliveryTarget) (map ditavalref-d) (map glossref-d) (topic hazard-d) (topic hi-d) (topic indexing-d) (topic markup-d) (topic pr-d) (topic relmgmt-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ui-d) (topic ut-d) (topic markup-d xml-d)

div.p: In order to run your test on a certain browser you need to do some architecture work such as initiating the webdriver of the given browser you want

ol.li: Every browser has a different webdriver. If you want cross browser testing you need to initialize a webdriver for every browser

section.p: Here you will find out how to initilize a webdriver :

li.span: Create a separate class named Hooks and use [Binding] annotation
Initiate the webdriver in a method and use [BeforeScenario] annotation over the method

section.p: You will be able to run your test in the given browser

div.p: To finish your test successfully you have to close your driver

section.p: Read the document of how to create your webdriver :
Here you will learn how to make the hook to be able to finish your test

li.span: Go to the Hooks class you have created
Close the webdriver in a method and use [AfterScenario] annotation over the method
Inherit the page hook into your class of the given page

section.p: You will be able to finish your test successfully

div.section: If you want to run your next test you will have to create a new webdriver. In order to create a new one you need to close the old one. That's why its so important to close your driver
